title: 107_hr1509
content: The Act is titled the "National Media Campaign to Prevent Underage Drinking Act of 2001" and amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national media campaign to prevent underage drinking. The Secretary is required to conduct a national media campaign to reduce and prevent underage drinking in the United States, in consultation with the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service and based on scientific evidence. The Secretary, in consultation with the Surgeon General, will develop a national media campaign based on scientific research to address underage drinking in the United States. The campaign will supplement existing efforts and not replace them. The Secretary will supplement existing efforts to prevent underage drinking in the United States and coordinate with other Federal agencies and departments. The Secretary will coordinate with various Federal agencies and departments, including CDC, NIAAA, SAMHSA, NIDA, DOJ, DOT, and ONDCP, to target prevention and treatment resources for consumers. The Secretary will use funds for a media campaign targeting prevention and treatment resources in specific geographic areas, with language-appropriate messages for minority groups. The Secretary will allocate funds for the national media campaign to meet reach and frequency goals. Funds can only be used for campaign development, strategy planning, and media time purchase. The funds allocated for the national media campaign can be used for developing a comprehensive strategy planning document, purchasing media time and space, talent reuse payments, out-of-pocket advertising production costs, testing and evaluation of advertising, evaluating the effectiveness of the media campaign, and negotiated fees for the winning. Funds available for the national media campaign can be used for testing and evaluating advertising, assessing the effectiveness of the media campaign, and negotiated fees for winning bidders on proposals. Additionally, funds may support partnerships with community and civic organizations. The funds available for the national media campaign can be used for partnerships with community, civic, and professional groups, as well as collaborations with the entertainment industry to create underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats. The funds can be used for partnerships with community groups and collaborations with the entertainment industry to create underage-drinking prevention messages in various media formats. None of the funds can be used to replace community-based efforts to prevent underage drinking. The funds available for underage-drinking prevention cannot be used to replace community-based efforts or for partisan political purposes. Additionally, the funds cannot be used for media campaigns featuring elected officials or federal officials. The funds for underage-drinking prevention cannot be used for partisan political purposes or media campaigns featuring elected or federal officials. The Secretary for Health must notify various committees before funding advertising messages with company logos. Non-Federal contributions are required for media purchases in the national campaign. The Secretary requires non-Federal contributions equal to 50% of media purchase price for the national campaign to prevent underage drinking. Reports to Congress on comprehensive strategy due within 6 months of enactment. The Secretary must develop and present a comprehensive strategy to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of the section, focusing on underage drinking prevention. The Secretary must present a comprehensive strategy to Congress within 6 months, focusing on underage drinking prevention. This includes a review of scientific research, target audiences, campaign goals, message points, implementation plan, evaluation plan, and estimated costs. Annual reports on activities funded under this section must be submitted to Congress. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on activities funded under this section, including details on the national media campaign's performance goals. Additionally, a progress report on the campaign's achievements must be submitted within one year of the section's enactment. A progress report on the campaign's achievements must be submitted within one year of the section's enactment. The term 'underage drinking' is defined as any consumption of alcohol by individuals below the legal purchasing age in the state. Funding authorization is provided for this purpose.
